                    <p class="article__teaser">People who get COVID-19 have a greater risk of developing diabetes up to a year later, even after a mild SARS-CoV-2 infection, compared with those who never had the disease, a massive study<sup><a href="#ref-CR1" data-track="click" data-action="anchor-link" data-track-label="go to reference" data-track-category="references">1</a></sup> of almost 200,000 people shows.</p>

readabilityObject.title: Diabetes risk rises after COVID, massive study finds
readabilityObject.content:
• NEWS
  • 31 March 2022

Even mild SARS-CoV-2 infections can amplify a personâ€™s chance of developing diabetes, especially for those already susceptible to the disease.

  1. Clare Watson

People who get COVID-19 have a greater risk of developing diabetes up to a year later, even after a mild SARS-CoV-2 infection, compared with those who never had the disease, a massive study1 of almost 200,000 people shows.
